clinical_study.brief_title: Rehab After Hip Fracture With Wearable Device
clinical_study.official_title: Assessing the Outcome of Rehabilitation After Hip Fracture With a Wearable Device

brief_summary.textblock: A randomized control trial, including three intervention arms with different methods for rehabilitation after hip fracture, conducted among persons with the need of rehabilitation in their own home.

detailed_description.textblock: The increase of the aging population challenges health care providers. Fragility, oste-oporosis, and impaired balance are some major risk factors for hip fracture, an injury causing morbidity, mortality, and loss of independent life. The aim of this study is to study the effect of three different interventions for rehabilitation after hip fracture. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial. Patients 65 years and older, with hip fracture that require rehabilitation at home, will be invited to participate in the study. Those who accept to participate will randomly be assigned to one out of three intervention groups. The first intervention includes rehabilitation according to High Intensity Functional Exer-cise (HIFE) and standard follow-up. The second intervention includes HIFE and follow-ups by means of a wearable inertial measurement unit (IMU). The control intervention includes standard rehabilitation protocol and standard follow-up via home visits and phone calls. The primary outcome is balance, in terms of postural sway measured with the IMU, and functional balance measured with the Functional Balance test for Geriatric patients, secondary outcomes are health-related quality of life, measured with the EQ5D and functional independence in everyday activities, measured with the Barthel Index.

arm_group.description: The intervention comprises the HIFE protocol as a rehabilitation method and, if necessary, other completing exercises. HIFE consists of five exercise categories depending on the capabilities of the patient.

arm_group.arm_group_label: High Intensity Functional Exercise and wearable sensor
arm_group.description: The intervention comprises the HIFE protocol as a rehabilitation method and, if necessary, other completing exercises. HIFE consists of five exercise categories depending on the capabilities of the patient. In addition, follow-up and feedback during the rehabilitation period will be given via a wearable inertial measurement unit (IMU).

The intervention comprises the standard rehabilitation services: walking training and adaptions to the walking pattern of the patient prior to surgery together with func-tional exercises. The intervention is tailored to each patient, based on the type of fracture, type of surgery, and assessment by the PT as well as treatment goals.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- patients with a hip fracture, living in Malm√∂, and who are unable to visit a rehabilitation facility and therefore request treatment at home. Another inclusion criterion is the ability to read and understand the Swedish language or the ability to understand information through an interpreter.
Exclusion Criteria:
- the presence of major neurological diseases that have an impact on balance and walk-ing ability; a diagnosed cognitive disease, or moderate to severe cognitive impairment as assessed by a physiotherapist
